thread.title: Dividend dazzlers and duds: what companies will pay this earnings season
thread.title_full: Dividend dazzlers and duds: what companies will pay this earnings season | afr.com

author: Les Hewitt, Vanessa Desloires
title: Dividend dazzlers and duds: what companies will pay this earnings season
text:
Two-thirds of ASX 200 companies reporting in August will lift their dividend payouts, Bloomberg says Jessica Shapiro by Les Hewitt, Vanessa Desloires The majority of Australia's top listed companies are​ set to boost their dividend payouts this year, despite a rocky past financial year which saw the ASX 200 gain just 1.2 per cent.
Bloomberg dividend forecasts estimate two-thirds of the 113 ASX 200 companies reporting earnings this more are expected to increase their payouts.
Shareholders in Oil Search can expect a 300 per cent increase in dividend per share, with the Papua New Guinea-based oil and gas company tipped to pay out 8¢ this year, compared with 2¢ this time last year.
Last month Oil Search lifted its 2015 production targets from 26 to 28 million barrels or equivalent to 27 to 29 mboe after hitting a record output for the quarter to June 30, but its revenue fell 17 per cent in the same quarter.
Rio Tinto is expected to increase its dividend the most, up 53 per cent from last year's 96¢ per share to $1.47. Louie Douvis For the blue chip holders, Rio Tinto is expected to increase its dividend the most, up 53 per cent from last year's 96¢ per share to $1.47, although lower than its February payout of $1.53.
Interestingly, Rio Tinto's dividend payouts have triggered rallies in its share price for the past two years under chief executive Sam Walsh's tenure.
Rival BHP Billiton however is expected to keep its dividend growth on hold this year, paying out 62¢ a share.
CSL is also expected to lift its dividend by a healthy 43 per cent, from 60¢ to 86¢. The payout seems justified given the biotechnology giant's share price crossed into the $100 mark on Tuesday , a milestone which has been charted by a 54 per cent rise in its share price in the past year alone.
 Proving some analyst's theories that Australian companies feel beholden to their yield-driven investors, the list of companies expected to boost their dividend payouts include beleaguered mining and mining services companies, including Iluka Resources, nickel miner Western Areas, Bradken Group and gold miner Northern Star Resources.
Bloomberg estimates that all of the big four banks will increase their dividends as expected, but in the shadow of looming increased capital requirements. ANZ Banking Group will increase its dividend slightly, from 95¢ to 97¢, while Commonwealth Bank shareholders will lift from $2.18 to $2.25.
Those companies set to cut their dividends include embattled companies Arrium and Metcash, which are are forecast to cut their payouts from 2.6¢ and 6¢ to zero respectively as they struggle to turn their fortunes around and lift back into profitability.
Fortescue Metals Group and Santos are also poised for a cut as they deal with plunges in iron ore and oil prices over the past year.
But the list is relatively small, just 13 companies opting to cut this year. This is despite challenging conditions over the past year in light of a slow down in China's economy, a broad-based fall in commodity prices, a strengthened US dollar and an Australian economy which is yet to navigate through a post-commodity boom landscape.
Morgan Stanley earlier this year said it expected growth in dividend payments would continue to outstrip earnings. Companies on the ASX 200 paid out a combined $90 billion in dividends in the first half of the 2015 financial year alone.
